attributes.title: Diversity and Conflict: Student Course Selection

q1.value: Diversity and Conflict: Student Course Selection

q3.value:
Purpose: Existing psychology literature on diversity and conflict is generally centered on the adult
workplace, while less attention is paid towards students in the university setting. More concretely,
little is known about students’ relationship to classroom diversity or their perceptions of classroom
(diversity-related) conflict. To that end, this study explores how students evaluate courses in light
of information about classroom diversity; particular attention is paid to how students may anticipate
and avoid conflict in more diverse, interactive courses. This research is critical in understanding
how students engage with an ever-diversifying world and, relatedly, ever-diversifying academy.
Moreover, this work attempts to probe this research question using methods and theory that
extend beyond traditional stereotyping and prejudice measurement procedures. Student
course selection: Many factors influence students’ choice of courses. These factors include
students’ majors, job aspirations, subject interests, and perceived level of course utility or value
(e.g., Beggs, Banthan, & Taylor, 2008; Eccles & Wigfield, 2002). Relatedly, students’ decisions
about what type of courses to take (i.e., lecture versus seminar) are informed by a host of factors,
including those aforementioned. However, the literature is mixed in its interpretations of whether
students prefer more ‘active learning’ courses to more traditional lecture-style courses (e.g.,
Machemer & Crawford, 2007; Struyven, Dochy, & Janssens, 2008). With these mixed findings, it is
difficult to infer students’ general preferences for or against classroom interactivity. It is yet more
difficult to infer students’ preferences for interactivity in diverse classrooms, as there has yet to be
an empirical investigation of the matter.  Present study: This study attempts to bridge this empirical
gap using undergraduate students. Students will be asked to reflect on the experience of a student
at a diverse vs. large university. Following this task, students will evaluate three fictional courses.
Students will also complete a series of potentially moderating measures (e.g., stress mindset,
social dominance orientation, etc.)

q4.value: As compared to the control condition, students in the diversity condition (especially those from less marginalized racial or ethnic backgrounds) will express lower preference for highly interactive, discussion-based courses as compared to lecture-style courses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Following recruitment and before lab participation [if applicable], participants will provide their consent and complete a battery of baseline measures (online and at a location of their choosing):
oMulticulturalism & Colorblindness Beliefs Scale (8 items)
oSocial Dominance Orientation (8 items)
oInterethnic Ideology (6 items)
oSocial Desirability (13 items)
oRace/Gender Identity Centrality (8 items)
oDiversity-Conflict IAT (participants will sort words into the categories diversity/homogeneity and/or harmony/conflict)
oExtra filler demographics (e.g., income, zip code, favorite movie, etc.)

At a separate date that has been chosen by the participant, they will then complete the full study: -Part 1: Self, Peers, and Environment
oIdentity Centrality (8 items)
oAttitudinal and Behavioral Openness Scale – Comfort with Differences (4 items)
oStress Mindset Measure (8 items)
oGeneral course preferences (3 items)
-Part 2: Student Perspectives [IV/PRIME]
oDiversity condition: After sharing their experiences, your friends ask you to tell them what your experience has been
like as a student on a diverse campus.
oControl condition: After sharing their experiences, your friends ask you to tell them what your experience has been
like as a student on a large campus.
-Part 3: Course Selection
oInterest in course (1 item)
oExpected workload (1 item)
oUtility of assignments (i.e., response papers, graded quizzes, discussion section) (3 items)
oGrading distribution preference (1 item)
oClass size preference (1 item)
-Part 4: Reaction Time Task
o Diversity IAT (participants will sort words into the categories diversity/homogeneity and/or good/bad)
-Demographics
All of these measures will be piloted ahead of time and may be piloted individually (e.g., the IAT measures).

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via the psychology undergraduate participant pool. Participants may also be recruited via Prolific, an online participant panel. In the case of Prolific, eligibility to view the study will be determined by having
indicated student-status on one's account -- there will be no in-study screening.

q13.value: Target accrual is 250 participants (target enrollment: 500). Data will also be analyzed using race/ethnicity, creating two groups of 'less' vs. 'more' racially-ethnically marginalized students.

question.value:
Data will be analyzed using
classical and multivariate statistical tools, including t-tests (e.g., to compare student subgroups), linear mixed models (e.g., to explore nuance in course preference as a function of course subject),  and general linear
models (e.g., to assess course grading distribution preference).

attributes.title: Specifications for PPI Use in Study Protocols for Randomized Controlled Trials of Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): A Systematic Review

summary.value:
REVIEW TITLE 
Specifications for PPI Use in Study Protocols for Randomized Controlled Trials of Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): A Systematic Methodology Review

AUTHORS
Jacob E Kurlander, Kevin Platt, Alex Kokaly, Danielle Helminski, Devraj Sukul, Hitinder Gurm, Sameer D Saini, Geoffrey D Barnes

START DATE 
1/30/20

ANTICIPATED COMPLETION DATE
Sept 1, 2020

ORGANIZATIONAL AFFILIATION OF REVIEW
University of Michigan

REVIEW TEAM MEMBER AND THEIR ORGANIZATIONAL AFFILIATIONS
Jacob E. Kurlander, MD, MS 1,2,3
Kevin Platt, MD 1
Alex Kokaly, BS 4
Danielle Helminski, MPH 1
Devraj Sukul, MD, MS 7
Hitinder Gurm, MD, MBBS 7,8
Sameer Saini, MD, MS 1,2,3,5
Geoffrey Barnes, MD, MSc 1,3,6

1. Department of Internal Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 
2. Veterans Affairs (VA) Ann Arbor Health Care System, Ann Arbor, MI
3. Institute for Healthcare Policy and Innovation, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
4. University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI 
5. VA Ann Arbor Center for Clinical Management Research, Ann Arbor, MI
6. Frankel Cardiovascular Center, Department of Internal Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
7. Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, Department of Internal Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI
8. Division of Cardiovascular Medicine, VA Ann Arbor Healthcare System, Ann Arbor, MI


FUNDING SOURCES
Kurlander: K23DK 118179-01A1

CONFLICTS OF INTEREST
None

REVIEW QUESTION
We will conduct a methodology review to evaluate the extent to which randomized controlled trials (RCTs) evaluating the efficacy and safety of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) of varying durations have taken measures in their study protocols to reduce the risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB), documented risk factors for UGIB, or characterized the source of gastrointestinal bleeding when it occurs.
We will use a recently conducted systematic review of DAPT trials published in 2019 (search completed in 2018) as the basis for identifying studies on this topic (CRD42018099519) 3. We will replicate and update the search strategy used in the previous systematic review to identify additional relevant studies published since the initial publication. 

CONDITION OR DOMAIN BEING STUDIED
Gastrointestinal bleeding in patients who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

CONTEXT
The COGENT trial, published in 2010, demonstrated that omeprazole reduces the risk of gastrointestinal events in patients treated with DAPT after PCI without increasing the rate of major adverse cardiovascular events 1. This formed the basis for professional society recommendations that PPI is appropriate in patients on DAPT 2. However, PPIs continue to be used at low rates in patients who receive DAPT after PCI.

ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA
This review follows the same criteria used in the systematic review being updated 3. All eligibility criteria from the original review will be identified below. 

PARTICIPANTS/POPULATION
Inclusion (per original study): 
•	Adults (aged ≥ 18 years) 
•	Patients receiving DAPT after the implantation of coronary stents

Exclusion (per original study): 
•	Patients who receive long-term warfarin or similar anticoagulant therapy
•	Patients who receive DAPT shorter than 3 months

INTERVENTION(S)/EXPOSURE(S) (per original study)
DAPT, defined as aspirin along with concurrent P2Y12 receptor antagonist (clopidogrel, prasugrel or ticagrelor) given for a period of either 3-6 months (short term), 12 months (standard), or >12 months (long-term). 

COMPARATOR(S)/CONTROL(S)
DAPT given for a different period of time, either short term, standard, or long term.

TYPES OF STUDIES TO BE INCLUDED
Inclusion (per original study):
•	RCTs comparing varying durations of DAPT
•	Clinical outcomes of included studies should include the following events: death, myocardial infarction (MI), or stroke
•	Sufficient data should be provided in original studies

Exclusion (per original study):
•	Analyses of non-randomized trials
•	Cross-sectional studies
•	Case reports or case series
•	Ongoing or prematurely terminated trials
•	Studies published in a language other than English  

MAIN OUTCOME
For this systematic review, the main outcome will be any specifications made about treatment with PPI therapy in the study protocol for patients on DAPT (e.g., all patients recommended to take PPI, PPI not allowed, treatment of PPI in specific sub-groups or at certain times, at the discretion of treating clinicians).

SECONDARY OUTCOMES
Specifications for evaluating prevalence of PPI use in participants, participant characteristics related to GI bleeding risk (including age, history of peptic ulcer disease or upper GI bleeding, NSAID use, PPI use), and how bleeding events are classified in each study (TIMI, Gusto, BARC, etc)

Inclusion (per original study):
•	All-cause mortality rate
•	Cardiac mortality rate
•	Frequency of myocardial infarction

TIMING OF THE EFFECT MEASURES
Per the original systematic review, cardiac mortality is defined as dying of myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure or cardiac arrest. Myocardial infarction includes both Q-wave and non-Q-wave type.

ADDITIONAL OUTCOME(S)
Additional outcomes will include: prevalence of PPI use in study participants during any portion of the time patients were treated with DAPT, specification of location of bleeding site (i.e., upper vs. lower gastrointestinal tract), bleeding classification system used (e.g., TIMI, BARC), other protocol specifications for reducing participants’ GI bleeding risk (e.g., no NSAID use). 


DATA EXTRACTION - SELECTION AND CODING
Titles and abstracts for articles will be screened independently by two reviewers (AK, KP) and all articles deemed to be potentially relevant at this stage will be retrieved in full text. The full text articles will be independently assessed by two reviewers (DH, AK) to determine eligibility for inclusion in this review. Any disagreements regarding full text study eligibility for inclusion will result in discussion between the two reviewers and adjudication by a third reviewer (JK) if necessary. For studies that are reviewed in full text but not eligible for inclusion, the reason for study exclusion will be documented. A flowchart following the PRISMA statement will be created to demonstrate the phases of this process. 
We will obtain the trial protocol for each study by reviewing the description of the study in the original publication, clinicaltrials.gov or any other trial registry used, reviewing journal websites for any supplemental information, or any other online resources referenced in the study publication. For RCTs where the trial protocol is not available, we will contact the primary author.

RISK OF BIAS (QUALITY) ASSESSMENT
Risk of bias will not be assessed as we are focused only on trial protocols and patient characteristics. 

STRATEGY FOR DATA SYNTHESIS
For all RCTs included in this systematic methodology review, including those previously identified in the 2019 publication as well as any additional articles found since the original search, two reviewers will independently extract the following data from the trial protocol: general information (authors, funding, conflicts of interest), study characteristics (inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, study duration), study protocol design (protocol specifications for PPI use in the trial, specifications for reducing participants GI bleeding risk, specifications for evaluating prevalence of PPI use in participants), participant characteristics related to GI bleeding risk (including age, history of peptic ulcer disease or upper GI bleeding, NSAID use, PPI use, H2 blocker use), and how bleeding events are classified in each study (TIMI, Gusto, BARC, etc). A standardized data extraction form will be used for documenting data for each included trial. This form will be piloted to determine whether any amendments are required. Any disagreements on data extraction will be resolved by discussion between the two reviewers. If the two reviewers are unable to reach a consensus, a third author will serve as arbiter. 
Results will be displayed in tables and discussed in narrative form. We do not plan to do a meta-analysis.


ANALYSIS OF SUBGROUPS OR SUBSETS
NA

q1.value: Evaluating Changes in Drinking Identity as a Mediator of the Relationship between Social Network Changes and Reductions in Drinking

q2.value: Kristen P. Lindgren, Clayton Neighbors, Scott Baldwin

q3.value: This research will test whether changes in drinking identity (DI) are associated with reductions in college student hazardous drinking (HD; heavy alcohol use and negative alcohol-related consequences) during the 2-year period following college graduation, a period which is traditionally associated with "natural" (i.e., without formal treatment) reductions in HD or "maturing out" of HD. We will also evaluate individuals’ social networks as a key factor related to these changes. Traditional explanations for maturing out of HD emphasize structural changes associated with changes in social networks (e.g., occupational changes, changes in family status; Arnett, 2000). We propose that changes in social networks will have a direct impact on changes in DI, which in turn will be associated with changes in HD. Thus, in this study we will assess individuals’ social networks and alcohol consumption in those networks, and evaluate changes in DI as a mediator of change in HD.

q4.value:
All hypotheses are directional. 
H1: Reductions in DI will lead to reductions in HD.
H2: Reductions in HD in one’s social network will lead to reductions in one’s own HD.
H3: Changes in DI will mediate the influence of social network changes on reductions in one’s own HD.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study is Study 1 of Kristen Lindgren's R01  (R01 AA024732, PI: Lindgren). Specific Aims for the grant as funded are attached.

This study has a longitudinal design and is correlational. More specifically, we planned to recruit  approximately 400 students in their last 4 months of college for a web-based study. We planned to evaluate their DI, HD, social networks (the 10 most important people with whom they regularly interact), and the drinking behaviors of the individuals in their social networks at 4-month intervals. Individuals would complete a baseline assessment and be followed for 2 years after they graduate for a total of 8 assessments.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
The hypotheses and aims of the study exist prior to data collection; they were specified in the original grant submission.

As of the time of pre-registration, we have accessed the data and conducted some analyses of the larger data set for secondary projects (please see Other for a description of the two published studies that make use of some of the larger data set). As a function of those projects and an unfunded grant submission that included some analyses of drinking variables and the implicit drinking variables over time, we are aware of some trends in the data due to analyses conducted for other projects. We had predicted in the original grant submission that that HD would decline over time and the existing analyses we conducted confirm that predicted.  We am not aware of whether DI increases or decreases over time. We are aware that the people in the network change from T1 to T3. We are not aware of whether the drinking of the network changes.

question.value:
Data collection for the study began in January 2016 and concluded in September 2019. 

Recruitment and participants:
 A sample of approximately 400 HD college students will be recruited from a large public university in the Pacific Northwest. They must attend the university full time and must be graduating in the next four months. A list of students meeting those criteria will be obtained from the university’s registrar’s office, and students will be approached to participate via email. To qualify for the study, individuals must be HDs; defined here as having scores of 8 or higher on the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT: Babor et al., 2001). Based on previous studies with similar populations, we anticipate approaching 3000 students to yield a sample of 400: we estimate a 35% response rate to email invitations and that 38% of those individuals will meet HD criteria. To yield a sample of approximately 400 that actually graduate we will recruit approximately 500 participants at baseline (T1). Participants whose college graduation cannot be confirmed following the T2 assessment will be dropped from the study.


Screening and Assessments: The initial screening and all assessments will be web-based. The screening will consist of demographic questions and the AUDIT, and respondents who meet the HD inclusion criteria (AUDIT scores of 8 or more) will be routed to the baseline assessment. Following the baseline assessment, subsequent assessments will be completed every 4 months over a 2-year period, yielding a total of 8 assessments. Each assessment will consist of implicit and explicit measures of DI; and self-reported measures of drinking (consumption, risk of alcohol use disorders, and problems), and social networks. The 4-month assessment interval is intended to be long enough to allow for changes in HD, but not so long as to miss meaningful change in overall levels of HD, and is consistent with other prospective studies of HDs in our Center.

Payment: Participants are not paid for screening. Participants who are eligible and complete the baseline (T1) assessment will  receive $25 as compensation. Follow-up assessments will follow similar procedures and will occur every 4 months after the baseline assessment for a two-year period. Participants will be invited to the follow-up sessions by email and will receive reminder emails, phone calls, or texts based on their preferences. Participants will receive $25 for each of the next three follow up assessments they complete. They will also receive a $25 bonus if they complete each of the first 4 assessments in the study. Participants will receive $30 for each of the last 4 follow up assessments they complete. They will receive a $25 bonus if they complete all of those assessments. In addition, at every assessment, participants who complete the assessment will be entered into a drawing for one of 4 $25 gift cards, a strategy which has been used successfully in other longitudinal studies in our Center.

q13.value:
524 individuals were initially enrolled in the study (we stopped data collection once we enrolled at least 500). There is a 36 hour delay between individuals completing the T1 assessment and our ability to access the data and review enrollment numbers, hence we anticipated that we might exceed 500 and set a stopping rule of ending enrollment once we had at least 500 paritcipants.

Following the T2 assessment, we began the process of confirming/verifying college graduation among our enrolled participants. Based on that process, 422 individuals remained eligible for the study and will be included in data analyses. The original grant analyses were powered based on a sample of 400 participants in the study.

q14.value:
Power analyses to determine sample size to test these hypotheses were conducted prior to grant submission and grant funding.  

Power analyses
---------------------------
We used Monte Carlo simulation to determine power given combinations of sample size and effect size (Muthén & Muthén, 2002). We set the Type I error rate to 0.05. We estimated power assuming the between- and within-person relationships are equal, as is commonly done. Power for the a, b, and c paths (see Figure 1) will always be higher than the indirect effect. Thus, we focused on power for the indirect effect. Figure 2 provides the computed power for the indirect effect across number of participants (each observed 8 times) stratified by effect size. The dashed line represents 90% power. The simulations indicated that 400 participants will be sufficient to detect an indirect effect that accounts for 20% of the total relationship between social network and HD with over 95% power (Preacher & Kelly, 2011). Further, if attrition is 10-15%, we will still have over 90% power.

question.value:
Participant gender - covariate

Variables we will measure (please note that each variable described below is measured at each of the 8 study timepoints).

Drinking Identity (2 measures)
---------------------------------------------------
Implicit DI will be measured via an adaptation of the Implicit Association Test (IAT; Greenwald et al., 1998), specifically the Drinking Identity IAT (Lindgren et al, 2013, Psychology of Addictive Behaviors).

Explicit DI will be measured using the Alcohol Self-Concept Scale (ASCS). The ASCS was adapted from the Smoker Self-Concept Scale (Shadel & Mermelstein, 1996) and used in Lindgren et al. (2013b), α = .94. 

Social Networks
--------------------------
Social Network Assessment. Social networks will be assessed using a modified version of the Important People Instrument (Longabaugh & Zywiak, 1999), which we have previously used to identify and recruit friends of HD students (Lee et al., 2014; Neighbors et al., 2012). We will also use modifications described in recent research examining social networks and drinking in college students (Barnett et al., 2014). Participants will be asked to list (first name and last initial) up to 10 people who are important to them and whom they interact with in-person on a weekly basis. These people may be friends, family members, people from work, or anyone that they see as having a significant impact on their life, regardless of whether or not they like them. Participants will be asked to report what each network member’s drinking is like with response options ranging from 1 to 4 (1 = ”doesn’t drink at all”, 2 = “light drinker,” 3 = “moderate drinker,” 4 = “heavy drinker”). Social network drinking at each time point will be scored as the mean drinking level of network members (range = 1-4). 

Hazardous Drinking (4 measures)
------------------------------------------------------
Alcohol consumption will be assessed with the Daily Drinking Questionnaire (DDQ; Collins et al., 1985) . Typical weekly drinking and typical drinks per occasion will be assessed with the DDQ.  Additional item will ask about the # of heavy drinking episodes (4/5 or more drinks per drinking occasions for women/men) in the last month.

Alcohol problems will be measured with the Rutgers Alcohol Problem Index (RAPI: White & Labouvie, 1989) and the AUDIT (Babor et al., 2001). The RAPI includes 23 alcohol-related consequences and will be used to assess the frequency of those consequences occurring over the past 4 months (α = .92). The AUDIT has 10 questions, which form 3 subscales assessing consumption, dependence, and alcohol-related problems.

Drinking Identity
---------------------------
Implicit DI: we will use the D1 score  as described in Greenwald et al. ,2003 as a our index of implicit identity
Explicit DI: we will create a mean score

Social Network
---------------------
Social Network Drinking: Participants are asked to describe each network member’s alcohol consumption. Responses are as follows: doesn’t drink at all (1), light drinker (2), moderate drinker (3), heavy drinker (4). We will create a summary score (mean) of network alcohol consumption. 

HD
-------
Consumption: the # of heavy drinking episodes we can use as-is; we will create a summary score (sum) of # of drinks consumed per week
Problems: we will creates sums  for AUDIT scores and for RAPI scores

We will use Structural Equation Modeling to address our hypotheses. We will estimate two models -- one that uses implicit drinking identity as the mediator and one that uses explicit identity as the mediator. We expect our procedures, such as transformations, inference plans, missing data exploration, etc. to be identical across the implicit and explicit identity models. 

We have eight time points. We will construct a latent variable, via confirmatory factor analysis, for Drinking Identity, Social Network, and Hazardous Drinking. Latent hazardous drinking within the social network will be constructed using measures from timepoints 2-3, latent drinking identity will be constructed using IAT measures (when modeling implicit identity) or explicit measures (when modeling explicit identity) from times 4-6, and latent hazardous drinking will be constructed using drinking measures from timepoints 7-8. Each of the latent constructs will be regressed on their respective time 1 (baseline) indicators. Thus, latent variables will represent changes from baseline levels.  

There will be three primary paths in the mediation model — a, b, and c. The “c” path will be the direct relationship between the latent social network and latent hazardous drinking and will address Hypothesis 2 — we expect a positive coefficient. The “b” path will be the direct relationship between latent identity and latent hazardous drinking and will address Hypothesis 1 — we expect a positive coefficient. The “a” path will be the direct relationship between latent social network and latent identity. The product of the a and b paths is the indirect effect (i.e., the mediation) and will address Hypothesis 3 — we expect a positive indirect effect.

The latent variables in the model will represent the stable portions of the variables across the specific time frame. For example, latent hazardous drinking within the social networks will represent the stable portion of drinking within the social network at times 2 and 3. The latent variables will be identified by fixing the variance of each latent variable to 1 and estimating the factor loadings. Hazardous drinking in the social network only has two indicators (i.e., time 2 and time 3). Consequently, the factor loadings for drinking in the social network will be estimated by constraining them to be equal. The same process will be followed for participants’ hazardous drinking. 

The models will include gender as a covariate. The (a) three latent variables, (b) time 1 hazardous drinking in the social network, (c) time 1 drinking identity, and (d) time 1 participants’ hazard drinking will be regressed on gender.

q20.value:
Transformations

We will dummy code gender, with female coded as 1 and male coded as 0 in the analysis (we did review responses to gender and no participant reported as identifying as anything other than male or female).

q21.value: As the hazardous drinking variables are count variables, we will not have access to traditional confirmatory fit statistics such as the Tucker Lewis Index or Root Mean Square Error of Approximation. We will establish statistical significance using p-values and we set our alpha at 0.05. If computationally feasible, which is unknown at this point due to multiple latent variables and non-normal data, we will bootstrap (anticipated 1000 bootstrap draws) the standard error for the indirect effect and construct a 95% confidence interval based on the bootstrapping. The indirect effect will be statistically significant if the confidence interval does not contain 0. If bootstrapping is not computationally feasible, we will use the delta method to construct the standard error.

q22.value:
Data will be screened prior to analyseis for any coding errors or impossible values. Rather than dropping any outliers, we will conduct sensitivity analyses to determine whether the outliers are strongly influencing the results. For example, we would estimate a model twice — once with the outlier and once without it — and compare the results. We plan to report the results of any sensitivity analysis in the report of this project. 

We also included accuracy checks in our surveys. There are three questions spread throughout the surveys that are meant to ensure that participants’ are paying attention and providing reasonable answers to questions. For example, participants are asked to "answer 'none of the above' on this question" and see a list of response options that includes 'none of the above' as well as other [incorrect] options. Any participant missing 2 or more accuracy questions will be excluded from analyses.

IAT scores are also screened. Any IAT scores where greater than 10% of the responses occurred in less than 300ms will be excluded, consistent with recommendations from Nosek and colleagues (Nosek et al., 2007).

q23.value:
We will use maximum likelihood to estimate our models. Maximum likelihood methods, as implemented in Mplus, will use all available data. For example, participants’ missing data from time 8 only, will contribute to estimates from time 1 - time 7. The analyses will be adequate provided that data are missing at random. 

We will explore the missing at random assumption by creating missing data indicators for key variables at each time point (1 = missing, 0 = not missing). We will then examine whether the frequency of missing data is higher based on known characteristics about the participants, such as baseline drinking (personal and social network), baseline identity, and gender. 

Given the high retention rate (retention through time 3 exceeded 90% and at our final assessment, retention exceeded 82%), we do not believe that non-random missing data is going to be a problem for our analyses. If we do notice some meaningful patterns, we will condition on any variables. Otherwise, we will follow recommendations for non-random missing data described in Enders C. K. (2010) Applied missing data analysis. New York: Guilford Press.

q24.value:
Exploratory Analysis

The primary hypothesis in this study is that drinking identity mediates the social network-personal drinking relationship. As an exploratory analysis, we also plan to repeat the models, but examine whether social network drinking mediates the drinking identity-personal drinking relationship. We do not anticipate any other changes to model except for changing what variable is the mediator.

registration_responses.q1: Evaluating Changes in Drinking Identity as a Mediator of the Relationship between Social Network Changes and Reductions in Drinking
registration_responses.q2: Kristen P. Lindgren, Clayton Neighbors, Scott Baldwin
registration_responses.q3: This research will test whether changes in drinking identity (DI) are associated with reductions in college student hazardous drinking (HD; heavy alcohol use and negative alcohol-related consequences) during the 2-year period following college graduation, a period which is traditionally associated with "natural" (i.e., without formal treatment) reductions in HD or "maturing out" of HD. We will also evaluate individuals’ social networks as a key factor related to these changes. Traditional explanations for maturing out of HD emphasize structural changes associated with changes in social networks (e.g., occupational changes, changes in family status; Arnett, 2000). We propose that changes in social networks will have a direct impact on changes in DI, which in turn will be associated with changes in HD. Thus, in this study we will assess individuals’ social networks and alcohol consumption in those networks, and evaluate changes in DI as a mediator of change in HD.
registration_responses.q4:
All hypotheses are directional. 
H1: Reductions in DI will lead to reductions in HD.
H2: Reductions in HD in one’s social network will lead to reductions in one’s own HD.
H3: Changes in DI will mediate the influence of social network changes on reductions in one’s own HD.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

As a function of those projects and an unfunded grant submission that included some analyses of drinking variables and the implicit drinking variables over time, we are aware of some trends in the data due to analyses conducted for other projects. We had predicted in the original grant submission that that HD would decline over time and the existing analyses we conducted confirm that predicted.  We am not aware of whether DI increases or decreases over time. We are aware that the people in the network change from T1 to T3. We are not aware of whether the drinking of the network changes.

registration_responses.q8.question:
This study is Study 1 of Kristen Lindgren's R01  (R01 AA024732, PI: Lindgren). Specific Aims for the grant as funded are attached.

This study has a longitudinal design and is correlational. More specifically, we planned to recruit  approximately 400 students in their last 4 months of college for a web-based study. We planned to evaluate their DI, HD, social networks (the 10 most important people with whom they regularly interact), and the drinking behaviors of the individuals in their social networks at 4-month intervals. Individuals would complete a baseline assessment and be followed for 2 years after they graduate for a total of 8 assessments.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data collection for the study began in January 2016 and concluded in September 2019. 

Recruitment and participants:
 A sample of approximately 400 HD college students will be recruited from a large public university in the Pacific Northwest. They must attend the university full time and must be graduating in the next four months. A list of students meeting those criteria will be obtained from the university’s registrar’s office, and students will be approached to participate via email. To qualify for the study, individuals must be HDs; defined here as having scores of 8 or higher on the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT: Babor et al., 2001). Based on previous studies with similar populations, we anticipate approaching 3000 students to yield a sample of 400: we estimate a 35% response rate to email invitations and that 38% of those individuals will meet HD criteria. To yield a sample of approximately 400 that actually graduate we will recruit approximately 500 participants at baseline (T1). Participants whose college graduation cannot be confirmed following the T2 assessment will be dropped from the study.


Screening and Assessments: The initial screening and all assessments will be web-based. The screening will consist of demographic questions and the AUDIT, and respondents who meet the HD inclusion criteria (AUDIT scores of 8 or more) will be routed to the baseline assessment. Following the baseline assessment, subsequent assessments will be completed every 4 months over a 2-year period, yielding a total of 8 assessments. Each assessment will consist of implicit and explicit measures of DI; and self-reported measures of drinking (consumption, risk of alcohol use disorders, and problems), and social networks. The 4-month assessment interval is intended to be long enough to allow for changes in HD, but not so long as to miss meaningful change in overall levels of HD, and is consistent with other prospective studies of HDs in our Center.

Payment: Participants are not paid for screening. Participants who are eligible and complete the baseline (T1) assessment will  receive $25 as compensation. Follow-up assessments will follow similar procedures and will occur every 4 months after the baseline assessment for a two-year period. Participants will be invited to the follow-up sessions by email and will receive reminder emails, phone calls, or texts based on their preferences. Participants will receive $25 for each of the next three follow up assessments they complete. They will also receive a $25 bonus if they complete each of the first 4 assessments in the study. Participants will receive $30 for each of the last 4 follow up assessments they complete. They will receive a $25 bonus if they complete all of those assessments. In addition, at every assessment, participants who complete the assessment will be entered into a drawing for one of 4 $25 gift cards, a strategy which has been used successfully in other longitudinal studies in our Center.

q2.value: Rachel Leshin, Daniel Yudkin, Marjorie Rhodes, Jay Van Bavel

q3.value: This study will explore young children's use of third-partly costly punishment. Specifically, this project aims to build off previous research documenting third-party punishment of moral transgressors by children as young as three years old (Yudkin, Van Bavel, & Rhodes, 2019). Here, we plan to run a pilot study to replicate this main finding from Yudkin et al. (2019) in a new online paradigm, testing both its robustness and generalizability.

q4.value: H1: Children will opt to punish targets who have transgressed to a greater degree than those who have not transgressed.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Note about blinding: Though children will not know the manipulation (and the treatment group to which they have been assigned), they will be aware of the stimuli presented.

question.value: This study will be a between-subjects, cross-sectional design. The two between-subjects variables examined will be whether or not the target transgresses.

q9.value: We will randomize at the level of the participant. Our study will be run through Qualtrics software, which randomly assigns participants to conditions that have been pre-programmed into the survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect all data via an online platform (the Princeton & NYU Discoveries in Action Lab, or “PANDA”) developed specifically for developmental research in our lab. We recruit participants for studies on this platform using a variety of methods, including community outreach events, social media advertising, and posts on Prolific. Thus, we have amassed a diverse group of potential participants from across the United States and the world. Given the objectives of this particular study, we will only recruit families who currently live in the United States and who have children between the ages of 5 and 8. Parents of eligible children will be contacted via email and offered the opportunity to participant in this research. Interested parents will then log into the PANDA platform and be directed to the study for which their child is eligible. Children and parents will then follow an online, IRB-approved consent and assent procedure. The study itself will be presented via short videos and verbally-narrated questions , which children will respond to by clicking on designated “buttons” provided. If children cannot click on the buttons themselves, parents will be encouraged to click for children (without altering their children’s responses or provide feedback in any way). At the end of the study, parents and children will be thanked for their participation and provided instructions on how to upload their child’s video, which approved PANDA researchers, including the lead researchers on this project, will be able to access. As compensation for participation, families will receive a $10 Amazon gift-card.

q13.value: We will aim to collect data from 40 participants.

q14.value: Our pilot N of 40 was established in accordance with norms in the field for pilot data.

question.value: For this pilot study, the only variable we will manipulate is whether or not the target child commits a transgression.

For this study, we plan to measure the following outcome measures:

(1) Child's binary choice to enact costly punishment toward a target.
Our pilot study will not make use of composite measures.

To test the effects of condition on punishment, we will use a chi-square test with condition as the independent variable and punishment decision (punishment versus no punishment) as the dependent variable.

q21.value: All analyses will rely on a critical p value of .05, two-tailed.

q22.value: We plan to exclude all trials in which children's responses appear to be influenced by parents or other environmental factors, as judged by two independent coders. These trials will be coded as "interferences," and any ambiguous coding will be resolved by a more senior member of the research team. Examples of interferences, as provided in the codebook, include: 1) Parents pointing/gesturing to answers with the intention of altering or determining a child's response, 2) Parents verbalizing a response that a child should choose, 3) Parents reframing a question in a way that emphasizes one answer to a greater degree than the others, 4) Parents providing context or any other information not originally provided by the study that children could incorporate into their responses, and 5) Parents providing validation for responses (e.g., saying "I agree"). All participants with more than 25% of trials marked as interferences will be excluded, as well.

q23.value: Partial data from participants will be included if at least 50% of items are complete; participants will less than 50% completion will be excluded.

q24.value:
Our planned exploratory analyses for the pilot are as follows:

-Does children's likelihood of costly punishment increase with age (with age treated as a linear variable)?
-Does liking the video more and wanting to watch the video in the future predict punishment decisions?
-Does condition predict perceptions of the target's actions as 'nice'?
-Does condition predict evaluations of whether or not the target should get to watch the video?
-Is there a correlation between perceptions of the target as 'nice' and the choice not to punish her?
-Does thinking that the target shouldn't get to watch the video relate to children's ultimate punishment decisions? 
-Does the time it takes children to punish the target relate to their ultimate punishment decisions?
-Is time-to-punish associated with age, gender, or condition? 
-Is time-to-punish associated with liking of video and/or punishment decision?
-Will punishment decision predict perceptions of how the target will feel at the end of the study?
-Will children predict that the target will be less likely to transgress in the future if she was punished?
-Is there a relation between children's attribution of the target's actions (intrinsic vs. extrinsic) and their punishment decisions? 
-Is there a relationship between children's endorsement of inherent explanations for the transgression and the predicted likelihood of future transgressions?
-In cases when pedagogical reasoning motivates punishment, is there a negative relationship between use of inherent explanations and decision to punish?
-Will children be less likely to want to play with the target if she transgressed?
-Will children be less likely to want to play with the target if they believe she will transgress again? 
-Will children be less likely to want to play with the target if they think she is a mean person?
-Does condition predict perceptions of how bad the target feels about her actions?
-Do perceptions that the target is a mean person predict how bad the target feels about her actions?
-In the transgression condition, do perceptions that the target may change (e.g., not transgress) in the future predict how bad the target felt about her actions?

registration_responses.q2: Rachel Leshin, Daniel Yudkin, Marjorie Rhodes, Jay Van Bavel
registration_responses.q3: This study will explore young children's use of third-partly costly punishment. Specifically, this project aims to build off previous research documenting third-party punishment of moral transgressors by children as young as three years old (Yudkin, Van Bavel, & Rhodes, 2019). Here, we plan to run a pilot study to replicate this main finding from Yudkin et al. (2019) in a new online paradigm, testing both its robustness and generalizability.
registration_responses.q4: H1: Children will opt to punish targets who have transgressed to a greater degree than those who have not transgressed.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7: Note about blinding: Though children will not know the manipulation (and the treatment group to which they have been assigned), they will be aware of the stimuli presented.
registration_responses.q9: We will randomize at the level of the participant. Our study will be run through Qualtrics software, which randomly assigns participants to conditions that have been pre-programmed into the survey.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: We will aim to collect data from 40 participants.
registration_responses.q14: Our pilot N of 40 was established in accordance with norms in the field for pilot data.
registration_responses.q21: All analyses will rely on a critical p value of .05, two-tailed.
registration_responses.q22: We plan to exclude all trials in which children's responses appear to be influenced by parents or other environmental factors, as judged by two independent coders. These trials will be coded as "interferences," and any ambiguous coding will be resolved by a more senior member of the research team. Examples of interferences, as provided in the codebook, include: 1) Parents pointing/gesturing to answers with the intention of altering or determining a child's response, 2) Parents verbalizing a response that a child should choose, 3) Parents reframing a question in a way that emphasizes one answer to a greater degree than the others, 4) Parents providing context or any other information not originally provided by the study that children could incorporate into their responses, and 5) Parents providing validation for responses (e.g., saying "I agree"). All participants with more than 25% of trials marked as interferences will be excluded, as well.

registration_responses.q8.question: This study will be a between-subjects, cross-sectional design. The two between-subjects variables examined will be whether or not the target transgresses.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will collect all data via an online platform (the Princeton & NYU Discoveries in Action Lab, or “PANDA”) developed specifically for developmental research in our lab. We recruit participants for studies on this platform using a variety of methods, including community outreach events, social media advertising, and posts on Prolific. Thus, we have amassed a diverse group of potential participants from across the United States and the world. Given the objectives of this particular study, we will only recruit families who currently live in the United States and who have children between the ages of 5 and 8. Parents of eligible children will be contacted via email and offered the opportunity to participant in this research. Interested parents will then log into the PANDA platform and be directed to the study for which their child is eligible. Children and parents will then follow an online, IRB-approved consent and assent procedure. The study itself will be presented via short videos and verbally-narrated questions , which children will respond to by clicking on designated “buttons” provided. If children cannot click on the buttons themselves, parents will be encouraged to click for children (without altering their children’s responses or provide feedback in any way). At the end of the study, parents and children will be thanked for their participation and provided instructions on how to upload their child’s video, which approved PANDA researchers, including the lead researchers on this project, will be able to access. As compensation for participation, families will receive a $10 Amazon gift-card.
registration_responses.q16.question: For this pilot study, the only variable we will manipulate is whether or not the target child commits a transgression.
registration_responses.q17.question:
For this study, we plan to measure the following outcome measures:

(1) Child's binary choice to enact costly punishment toward a target.
registration_responses.q18.question: Our pilot study will not make use of composite measures.
registration_responses.q19.question: To test the effects of condition on punishment, we will use a chi-square test with condition as the independent variable and punishment decision (punishment versus no punishment) as the dependent variable.

q3.value: The study surveys a sample of German residential tenants on how they evaluate physical defects that befall their apartment during the lease term. This will generate empirical insights into the usefulness  of the "Mietminderung" remedy of German lease law. These insights may inform the doctrinal construction of⁠—and evidence-based policy-making in⁠—lease law.

q4.value: The study is exploratory and will produce sample estimates in hopes of generalizing to the population of German renters by approximating a representative sample as closely as possible.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
This online survey employs a vignette design in a (German-language) Qualtrics questionnaire. It consists of three parts:

1. After presenting the consent form and confidentiality disclaimer, respondents are asked to identify their present living situation and current rent amount, which will be referred to in later vignettes to help respondents calibrate to familiar values.

2. The main part of the study asks respondents to consider imagined scenarios (vignettes) about home defects. It combines variation within and between subjects:
a. within subjects: Each respondent gets presented five different vignettes and three combinations of 2-3 of these five vignettes. Vignettes get presented in random order with an intermittent reset screen, but no feedback in between.
b. between subjects: Four experimental variations get administered on each of the five vignettes through minor textual changes. These create one control condition to obtain a baseline valuation and three treatments of increasingly severe defects. Respondents are randomly assigned to one condition and do not learn about the existence of other conditions.

3. On the last screen of the questionnaire, respondents are asked for demographic information (residence location, number of previous relocations, relevant disabilities, age of (co-)inhabitants, annual income, education and degree), and lastly asked to provide comments in a free-text input field.

q9.value: Simple randomization of the vignette sequence (within subjects) and of the assignment to treatments (between subjects) are both implemented in Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: A pilot run of (a prior version of) the survey took place on 8 Jan 2020 with 13 respondents. This data was used exclusively to revise the questionnaire and the sampling approach. It will not be used in the analysis, and respondents will be precluded from entering the main study.

question.value:
Respondents are recruited from the online participant pool of Prolific (www.prolific.co) and paid €1.50 for agreeing to take the survey (plus up to €48 in additional incentive bonuses). Using the platform's demographic filters, respondents get pre-screened to include only German-speaking renters residing in Germany. To approximate a representative sample as closely as possible, gender and age screeners will be combined to compose a stratified sample from several recruitment waves:
1. On a regular workday at 7 a.m., the first wave opens to respondents in the gender ratio recorded in the overall population census: 51 female, 49 male.
2. On the same workday at 7 p.m., to neutralise time-of-day effects, the second wave opens to another 51 female and 49 male respondents.
3. A target sample size (N*) gets calculated using only age and gender data from the first two waves: N* = number of observations for the most frequent age-gender-combination, divided by its corresponding share in the 2019 census.
4. Once N* has been calculated, additional respondents will be recruited from every age-gender-combination except the most frequent one until the proportion in each age-gender-cell matches the corresponding census proportion as closely as possible.

q13.value: The sample size gets determined using the data collection procedure outlined above. Its exact value depends on patterns in the response rate, but will be no less than 200 and likely no more than 400.

q14.value: At the minimum of 200 subjects, each of the four experimental conditions would receive 50 responses, which is considerably larger than the 30 observations per cell commonly assumed to warrant reliance on the Central Limit Theorem.

q15.value: Since the online subject pool may not reach enough respondents in each age-gender-cell to construct the stratified sample envisioned in the data collection procedure, recruitment will conclude no later than two weeks from the start of wave 1, even if some age-gender-combinations remain underrepresented in the sample.

question.value: There are four outcome measures recorded from each vignette: Respondents are asked to estimate (1) the subjectively reasonable rent reduction in the scenario, (2) their own subjective confidence in (1) on a six-level Likert item, (3) the estimated average response of all other survey respondents to (1), and (4) the estimated average response of German judges in pertinent court decisions. The latter two measures are openly incentivized: The closer that respondents come to the observed actual value, the higher their chances of winning a bonus payment of 4 € in addition to the lumpsum of 1.50 € for survey completion.
The analysis relies on descriptive statistics and will likely not require statistical inference or model assumptions.

q22.value: The questionnaire contains a cognizable awareness check within the demographics section. Respondents failing this check will be excluded from payments, and analysed separately.

attributes.title: The role of payoff information on the interpretation of individual actions in a joint-action context

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The role of payoff information on the interpretation of individual actions in a joint-action context. Replication with modified test stimuli.

sample.value: The minimum sample will consist of 16 subjects who contributed data. The maximum sample size will consist of 32 subjects. We will terminate our data collection either after we collect 32 valid data sets or when the base-10 logarithm of the Bayes factor in the looking-time analysis (calculated assuming variable effect size as described in Csibra et al., 2016) is larger than +1, which would indicate a strong effect in the predicted or opposite direction.

analyses.value: We will perform analyses on log-transformed looking times, as this type of data tends to be log-normally distributed. We will calculate Bayes factors with a Bayesian analysis proposed by Csibra, Hernik, Mascaro, Tatone & Lengyel (2016) for infant looking time data. In addition, we will run a paired t-test (two-tailed) to compare the means of the looking times to the two test outcomes. To check for possible order effects (since infants tend to look longer at the first test video presented), we will run a mixed ANOVA (and, if there is a significant Order x Test event interaction, separate t-tests for the two groups of infants: those who saw the test with the giving test first, and those who saw it second).

dependent.value: The dependent variable is infants’ looking time to two different test trials. The infants will watch one event consistent with the previously shown stimuli, and another that is inconsistent. Infants’ looking behaviour will be coded online by an experimenter. For analyses, looking times will be also coded offline from videos of the participants. To ensure reliability, a coder blind to the experimental hypothesis will re-code looking times of 50% of the sample, after data collection is completed.

conditions.value: There is only one between-subject condition: test order (giving first vs. giving second). The factors that we will counterbalance across infants are the identity of the agent giving at test (A vs. C) and side of A or C in the joint-action events (left vs. right).

hypothesis.value:
In a previous looking-time study, we found that 12-month-old infants familiarized to an agent A participating in a joint activity which resulted in a reward for another agent B, but not herself, and another agent C participating in an identical joint activity with the same agent B, but which resulted in a reward for both agents, looked longer at test to agent B being the recipient of a giving action performed by C rather than A. 

We interpreted these results as suggesting that the costly involvement of agent A in the joint activity, in the absence of personal rewards, primed the representation of a prosocial goal, of which giving is also an instance. Conversely, since the involvement of agent C could be readily explained by appealing to the rewards obtained, infants did not attribute to this agent any prosocial goal with which giving may have been conceptually related to. 

Alternatively, however, infants may have simply looked longer to C giving to B because they detected a change in the number of overall objects in the scene, since in familiarization each agent acquired 1 object, whereas at test only the recipient (B) acquired one. 

The present study seeks to conceptually replicate our previous findings with modified test stimuli that would allow us to rule out this alternative account based on the change of object numerosity from familiarization to test. To this end, we will modify the test events so that there will be two objects (both initially possessed by the Giver) on the scene: one given to B, and the other one remaining in possession of agent A/C.
